member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat
member.summary: Represents a Microsoft Windows Bitmap (BMP) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: BMP files are simple, native Windows raster images. In general, BMPs are much larger than formats such as JPEG or PNG. They do not scale as well as vector files and may appear blocky or jagged when increased in size. BMPs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.

(The default value is true)

member.summary: Gets or sets if a georeferenced world file will be created.

remarks.para: If set to true, the file will contain pixel scale and real-world coordinate information. World files are not generated for Layout exports.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EMFFormat
member.summary: Represents an Enhanced Metafile Format (EMF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: EMF files are native Windows graphics files that can contain a mixture of vector and raster data. They are useful for embedding in Windows documents because the vector portions of the EMF can be resized without loss of quality. However, since EMF does not support font embedding and is exclusively a Windows format, it is not commonly used as an interchange format between users.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat
member.summary: Represents an Encapsulated Postscript (EPS) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: EPS files use the PostScript page description language to describe vector and raster objects. PostScript is the publishing industry standard for high-end graphics files, cartography, and printing. EPS files can be edited in many drawing applications or placed as a graphic in most page layout applications. EPS files support embedding of fonts so that users who do not have Esri Fonts installed can still view the proper symbology.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat.ImageCompressionQuality
member.summary: This value (0100) controls the amount of compression applied to the output image. With a JPEG image, quality is adversely affected the more compression is applied. A higher quality (highest = 100) setting will produce sharper images and larger file sizes. A lower quality setting will produce more image artifacts and smaller files.
member.remarks: (The default value is 80)

member.remarks: GIF files are a legacy raster format for use on the web. GIFs cannot contain more than 256 colors (8-bits per pixel), which along with optional lossless compression, makes them smaller than other file formats.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.JPEGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG) format object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: JPEG files are compressed image files. They support 24-bit color and are a popular choice for use on the web because a JPEG file size is often substantially smaller than many other image formats. However, the JPEG compression algorithm is lossy and is not recommended for many map images, as line drawings, and text or icon graphics become blurred by compression artifacts. Therefore, PNG is usually a superior format for map images. JPEGs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.

member.remarks: (The default value is 80)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PDFFormat
member.summary: Represents a Portable Document Format (PDF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: PDF files are designed to be consistently viewable and printable across different platforms. They are commonly used for distributing documents on the Web and are becoming a standard interchange format for content delivery. PDFs are editable in many graphics applications and can retain annotation, labeling, and attribute data for map layers. PDF exports from support embedding of fonts and thus can display symbology correctly even if the user does not have Esri fonts installed.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PNGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Portable Network Graphics (PNG) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: PNG is a versatile raster format that can display in web browsers and inserted into other documents. It supports high-bit-depth color and uses a lossless compression. For maps, PNG is often the best raster format, since the lossless compression keeps text and line work legible by preventing the compression artifacts that can occur in JPEG format. PNGs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SVGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: SVG is an XML-based file format that has been specifically designed for viewing on the Web. SVG can contain both vector and raster information. This is a good choice for displaying maps on a web page because it is rescalable and more easily edited than raster files. SVG has been gaining in popularity since the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) selected it as their standard vector Web format. Some Web browsers may require a plug-in to view SVG files; older browsers may not be able to view SVG files at all.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TIFFFormat
member.summary: Represents a Tagged Image File Format (TIFF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: TIFF files are the most versatile raster format. TIFFs can store pixel data at several bit depths and can be compressed with either lossy or loss less compression techniques depending on file size and accuracy requirements. They are the best choice for importing into image editing applications across operating systems. They cannot be natively viewed by a web browser. TIFFs exported from a Map or MapFrame also support georeferencing information in GeoTIFF tags or in a separate world file for use as raster data.

remarks.para: If set to true and a valid GeoReferenceMapFrameName is set, a world file will be generated based on the map frame's coordinate system.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PrinterSettings
member.summary: Provides a base set of properties that all export formats inherit.

remarks.para: When exporting a MapView, the size of the output image is based on the Resolution and the Height and Width properties. For example, if the output resolution is 96 and height and width are both 960 then the output image size will be 960 pixels by 960 pixels and 10 inches by 10 inches. The geographic area for an exported MapView is generated based on its location which represents the center of the view.

When exporting a Layout or a MapFrame, the height and width are obtained from the size of the object in page units and the Height and Width properties are ignored. For example, if a MapFrame is 5 inches by 5 inches and the resolution is 300, the output image will be 1500 pixels by 1500 pixels and remain 5 inches by 5 inches.

member.returns: A map.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: To open a map, use ProApp.Panes.CreateMapPaneAsync method.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IMapFactory.ConvertMap(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert the input map to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported: o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Technically, there is no difference between the Scene (Global) or Scene (Local). It merely indicates the nature or their underlying coordinate system (i.e. "global" or "local").
The intended conversion can be tested by calling the method first.
Specifying openView=true will open a new view for the converted map. The method will return without waiting for the view to initialize and begin drawing. This is an optimization to prevent Pro being loaded down with viewer initialization if this method is called within a loop to create multiple maps. The correct way to detect viewer initialization is via the . The event will fire after the first draw of the new view has been initiated.
member.param: The map to convert
The type to convert the map to
true to open a map pane for the newly converted map
member.returns: The converted
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Cannot convert {map} to {conversion type}
Failed to convert the map viewing mode

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IMapFactory.ConvertMapFromItem(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapProjectItem,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert the input map item to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported (the map referenced by the map item is tested): o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Technically, there is no difference between the Scene (Global) or Scene (Local). It merely indicates the nature or their underlying coordinate system (i.e. "global" vs "local").
The intended conversion can be tested by calling the method first.
Specifying openView=true will open a new view for the converted map (in the item). The method will return without waiting for the view to initialize and begin drawing. This is an optimization to prevent Pro being loaded down with viewer initialization if this method is called within a loop to create multiple maps. The correct way to detect viewer initialization is via the . The event will fire after the first draw of the new view has been initiated.
member.param: The map item to convert
The type to convert the map item to
true to open a map pane for the newly converted map item
member.returns: The converted
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Cannot convert {map} to {conversion type}
Failed to convert the map viewing mode

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IMapFactory.CanConvertMap(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType)
member.summary: Determines whether the map can be converted to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported: o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Specifying an invalid conversion type will return false
Note: If MapConversionType.SceneGlobal is specified, if the map spatial reference contains a vertical coordinate system, the VCS is checked to see if it is compatible with a global scene. If it is not, the method will also return false
member.param: The map to test
The type to convert the map to
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Specifying an invalid conversion type will return false
Note: If MapConversionType.SceneGlobal is specified, if the map item's map spatial reference contains a vertical coordinate system, the VCS is checked to see if it is compatible with a global scene. If it is not, the method will also return false
member.param: The map item to test

summary.para: Defines the method used to link multiple 2D and 3D views together.
This enumeration has a FlagsAttribute attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LinkMode.None
member.summary: Views are not linked.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LinkMode.Center
member.summary: Views will look at the same location. When linking 2D and 3D views, the locations are approximated.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LinkMode.Scale
member.summary: Views will maintain the same scale and rotation. When linking 2D and 3D views, the scales are approximated between view types.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera
member.summary: Represents an object that defines the displayed content of a view via its viewing location and viewing direction.

remarks.para: Both 2D and 3D views define and manage what is being displayed using a camera object. You can get the current camera for the view using the property.

In 2D, the camera defines its viewing location using and . The values are in the same units as those defined by the camera's . This will be the center point of the 2D view's extent. The viewing direction, or rotation, of the map is defined using the camera's property. The camera's property then defines how far the view is zoomed in or out, and the 2D view will be able to display content for that area. You can also get the extent from the view using the property.

In 3D, the camera defines its viewing location using , and . As with 2D, the values are stored in the same units as those defined by the camera's , with the additional possibility that XY units and Z units may be different. This will be the central position for the 3D view, as though a helicopter was hovering in that location. The viewing direction is defined by a combination of the , , and properties, which will rotate, tilt, and roll how the camera looks at the content around it, and the 3D view will be able to display content for the defined frustum.

member.summary: Initialize a new instance of a Camera.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.X
member.summary: Gets or sets the X position of the Camera, in the units of the camera's spatial reference. This property applies to both 2D and 3D views.
member.remarks: X, Y, Z, and SpatialReference are used to describe the viewing location. X defines the x coordinate of the camera location.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Y
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y position of the Camera, in the units of the camera's spatial reference. This property applies to both 2D and 3D views.
member.remarks: X, Y, Z, and SpatialReference are used to describe the viewing location. Y defines the y coordinate of the camera location.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Z
member.summary: Gets or sets the Z position of the Camera, in the units of the camera's spatial reference. This property applies to 3D views only.
member.remarks: X, Y, Z, and SpatialReference are used to describe the viewing location. Z defines the z coordinate of the camera location.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the Scale of the Camera, as a ratio of distance on the map to reality. This property applies to 2D views only.
member.remarks: The Scale property defines the ratio of distance on the map to the corresponding distance on the ground in 2D views. The Scale property value is expressed as a double representing the value on the right side of the ratio. For example a value of 1000 is equal to a scale of 1:1000.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Pitch
member.summary: Gets or sets the Pitch of the Camera, in degrees from horizontal. 0 is horizontal, 90 is looking directly up and -90 is looking directly down. This property applies to 3D views only.
member.remarks: Heading, Pitch and Roll are used to describe the viewing direction in a 3D view. Pitch defines the angle of the camera rotating around the X-axis. Imagine yourself as the camera. In this case adjusting the pitch would be equivalent to looking up or down. The valid range for pitch is -90 (looking directly down) to 90 (looking directly up). Pitch has no effect in 2D it will always be -90.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Roll
member.summary: Gets or sets the Roll of the Camera, in degrees around the view vector. 0 is no roll, 45 rolls the right side down, -45 rolls the left side down. This property applies to 3D views only.
member.remarks: Heading, Pitch and Roll are used to describe the viewing direction. Roll defines the angle of the camera rotating around the Y-axis. Imagine yourself as the camera. In this case adjusting the roll would be equivalent to tilting your head. There is currently no way to change the roll using the out of the box navigation tools. If roll is set to anything other than 0 and you attempt to navigate in the view the roll will be set back to 0. For most workflows in 3D roll will never be changed and remain its default value of 0. Roll has no effect in 2D it will always be 0.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Heading
member.summary: Gets or sets the Heading of the Camera, in degrees from North. 0 is North, 90 is West, 180 is South, -90 is East, etc. This property applies to both 2D and 3D views.

remarks.para: Heading, Pitch and Roll are used to describe the viewing direction in a 3D view. Sometimes referred to as Yaw, Heading defines the angle of the camera rotating around the Z-axis. Imagine yourself as the camera. In this case adjusting the heading would be equivalent to looking to the left or right. The valid range for heading is -180 to 180 which are equal looking south. A value of 0 is looking north.
Heading is the one viewing direction property that is also used in 2D view. In a 2D view Heading determines and will determine the rotation of the view.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.Viewpoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the Viewpoint of the Camera. This property applies to both 2D and 3D views.
member.remarks: You can use a Camera to define either the coordinate that you are looking from (the observer) or the position that you are looking at (the target). If you set the Viewpoint to be LookFrom, the Camera viewing location will be the coordinate of the observer. If you set the Viewpoint to be LookAt, the Camera viewing location will be the coordinate of the target.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.ViewportHeight
member.summary: Gets or set the height of the viewport (in meters), required for consistent isometric camera positioning.
member.remarks: ViewportHeight and ViewportWidth are used to define the view extent when Isometric Drawing Mode is enabled. In Perspective mode the width and height are naturally defined by the camera's field of view, but in Isometric mode the light rays are parallel so additional information is required. If these parameters are set to less than or equal to 0, a width and height will be estimated based on the camera's distance from the surface, which may lead to inconsistent isometric view extents in bookmarks, animations, and exported views.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.ViewportWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the viewport (in meters), required for consistent isometric camera positioning.
member.remarks: ViewportHeight and ViewportWidth are used to define the view extent when Isometric Drawing Mode is enabled. In Perspective mode the width and height are naturally defined by the camera's field of view, but in Isometric mode the light rays are parallel so additional information is required. If these parameters are set to less than or equal to 0, a width and height will be estimated based on the camera's distance from the surface, which may lead to inconsistent isometric view extents in bookmarks, animations, and exported views.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera.SpatialReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the Spatial Reference of the Camera. This property applies to both 2D and 3D views.
member.remarks: X, Y, Z, and SpatialReference describe the position of the viewing location. Setting an appropriate spatial reference for the position of the camera allows the camera to be applied across views with different spatial references. The camera's relative location to the Earth remains unchanged. Project the camera if its spatial reference has a different datum than the map's spatial reference using the api. If the spatial reference is null the camera assumes the spatial reference of the map to which it is applied.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView
member.summary: Represents a view of a map (2D) or a scene (3D).

remarks.para: A project can contain multiple maps, either 2D or 3D, and each defines the collection of layers that make up that map. A map view is simply a view of a map. Map views are the primary interface used to display, navigate, select, identify, and edit data in a 2D or 3D map. The MapView class provides properties and methods to navigate and interact with layers in the map. The map being visualized in the view can be accessed via the property.

There can be multiple map views open at a given time, but there can only be one active map view. The active map view will set the context for the ribbon and many of the dock panes in the application. For example, the map Contents pane will reflect the layers of the active map view's map. The instance of the active map view can be accessed via the static the property. The active property will return null if there is no active map view. This is useful when writing commands designed to interact with the active map.

The map view also provides the context for the selected items in the Contents pane. For example, the method returns the collection of layers that are currently selected in the Contents pane. This context is used to determine which contextual tabs to show, for example, when one or more feature layers are selected, the Feature Layer tab group will display, and the commands will act on the selected feature layers. This is useful when writing commands to work with the selected items in the Contents pane.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.Active
member.summary: Gets the active map view. Returns null if there is no active map view.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.LinkMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the method used to link views.
member.exception: Scale can only be set in combination with Center.
member.remarks: View linking is a navigation experience and can be used for multiple maps, scenes, or a mix of these 2D and 3D views. When you enable view linking all views will update their extents to match depending on the link mode that is selected. Currently the link mode Scale can only be used in combination with Center. Center can be used on its own or in combination with Scale.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.Map
member.summary: Gets the map or scene associated with the view.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.Animation
member.summary: Gets the animation for the view.
member.remarks: This property will return null if the map's contains no keyframes. Similar to how the map defines the layers that make up the map, the map defines the animation and the keyframes for all views of the map. However, it is possible to have multiple views of a map set to different times in the animation. This property returns an object can be used to set the current time or frame, step to the next or previous keyframe, or play and stop the animation.

member.summary: Gets or sets the time range visible in the map view.
member.remarks: This property is null when there are no time aware layers in the map. When the Time property is not null, but both the and properties of the are null this means the map view is showing all time. This is equivalent to disabling time in the map view. Setting this property to null when there are time aware layers in the map will set both the start and end properties of the to null.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.Range
member.summary: Gets or sets the range extent visible in the map view.
member.remarks: This property is null when there are no layers with an active range in the map. When the Range property is not null, but both the and properties of the are null this means the map view is showing all values. This is equivalent to disabling range in the map view. Setting this property to null when there are layers with an active range in the map will set both the min and max properties of the to null.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.FloorFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the floor filter settings which determine which floor-aware data is visible in the map view.
member.remarks: This property is null when the Indoors Layers properties have not been defined for the map. When the Indoors Layers properties have been defined, floor filtering on the map is enabled. Layers which have been defined to be floor-aware will have their data filtered according to selections made in the floor filter.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.ViewingMode

member.remarks: This property is used to determine whether the view is displaying a 2D map or 3D scene. A map view can be used to show maps which display 2D data or scenes which display 3D data. For a 3D view SceneLocal and SceneGlobal are valid view modes for the scene.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.CancelDrawing
member.summary: Stop the current drawing of the MapView.
member.remarks: Only the current draw is canceled. Anything that would normally cause the view to start drawing will still do so.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.PanToAsync(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Pan the view to a camera position.
member.param: The new camera to use for the view.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the default navigation duration.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.
member.remarks: Pan in 2D maintains the current camera scale and heading and modifies the X and Y position. Pan in 3D maintains the current camera pitch and heading and modifies the X and Y position. If the camera's spatial reference is in a different spatial reference than the map this method projects the camera into the spatial reference of the map.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.PanTo(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Pan the view to a camera position. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: The new camera to use for the view.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the default navigation duration.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.
member.remarks: Pan in 2D maintains the current camera scale and heading and modifies the X and Y position. Pan in 3D maintains the current camera pitch and heading and modifies the X and Y position. If the camera's spatial reference is in a different spatial reference than the map this method projects the camera into the spatial reference of the map.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.ZoomToAsync(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Zoom the view to a camera position.
member.param: The new camera to use for the view.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the default navigation duration.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to setting the camera position for the view. Use this method in combination with to get and then modify the position of the view's camera. If the camera's spatial reference is in a different spatial reference than the map this method projects the camera into the spatial reference of the map.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.ZoomToAsync(ArcGIS.Core.Geometry.Geometry,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Zoom the view to the extent defined by a geometry.
member.param: The geometry defining the extent in which to zoom.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the default navigation duration.

Indicates if the Pitch and Heading should remain the same after the navigation is completed. If false the Heading will be set to 15.0 and the Pitch will be set to -60.0. This parameter only effects 3D views.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to setting the extent of the view. Use this method in combination with the property to get and then modify the view's extent. If the geometry's spatial reference is in a different spatial reference than the map this method projects the geometry into the spatial reference of the map.

member.summary: Zoom the view to the extent of one or more features.
member.param: The collection of layers and corresponding Object IDs in which to zoom.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the transition time property set for the application.

Indicates if the Pitch and Heading should remain the same after the navigation is completed. If false the Heading will be set to 15.0 and the Pitch will be set to -60.0. This parameter only effects 3D views.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView.LookAtAsync(ArcGIS.Core.Geometry.MapPoint,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Center the view at a given point.
member.param: The point to center the view at.
The amount of time to navigate the view to the new camera position. If null it uses the transition time property set for the application.
member.remarks: In 2D this will center the view on the given point, it will not adjust the Scale or Heading of the view. In 3D this will maintain X, Y, and Z for the camera and adjust the Heading and Pitch so that the provided point is at the center of the view.
member.returns: True if the navigation is completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.

member.summary: Initializes an empty instance of the class.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.ExportTileCacheParams.DestinationFolder
member.summary: Gets and sets the folder into which the local tile cache(s) will be copied (optional).
member.remarks: If left null or empty, the destination folder defaults to the Offline Maps location specified for the current project in the project properties. Typically this is the current project folder

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.ExportTileCacheParams.Extent
member.summary: Gets and sets the extent of the area to be included in tile cache.
member.remarks: The spatial reference of the specified extent must be the same as the map from which tile cache is being generated

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.ExportTileCacheParams.MaximumUserDefinedScale
member.summary: Gets and sets the maximum scale of data in the tile cache.
member.remarks: Use and to get a list of available scales for tile cache content in the map. The selected scale specified in MaximumUserDefinedScale is compared to the LODs of the tile cache content in the map to determine the specific LOD for a given tile cache to export. The LOD, for a given tile cache, containing the specified scale is the LOD that will be used.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap
member.summary: Provides support for taking map content offline, to include: Generating, syncing, and removing replicas for a given map's content. Support is also included for exporting raster and vector tile caches.
member.remarks: Refer to Take a map offline in the Pro documentation for the corresponding UI functionality

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.Instance
member.summary: The singleton instance of GenerateOfflineMap.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.GetCanExportRasterTileCache(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map)
member.summary: Gets whether the map contains one or more raster tile caches that can be exported. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.

member.summary: Get the list of scales to use for determining the level of detail, LOD, to use when exporting a raster tile cache. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
If there are multiple raster services present in the TOC then the returned list of scales is derived from a consolidation of all LODs for the raster services (within the specified extent)
The extent parameter should be the same extent that is used with the when exporting the tile cache.
The extent spatial reference must match the spatial reference of the map or an exception will be thrown.
If the map has no exportable raster services then an empty list is returned. Raster tile caches include tiled map services and image services.
member.param: The map containing the raster services
The extent controls the range of scales. A larger extent will usually result in a greater number of scale ranges than a smaller extent.
member.returns: A list of scales or an empty list if there are no exportable raster tile caches
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Map cannot be null
Extent cannot be null or empty
Map and extent spatial references must be equal

member.summary: Gets whether the map contains sync-enabled content. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Sync-enabled content refers to content in the map being sourced from sync-enabled feature services. Note: if the sync-enabled content is from a branch versioned feature service then the branch version must be the default version.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.GenerateReplicas(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateReplicaParams)
member.summary: Generate bi-directional replicas for all sync-enabled content in the map. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
To generate a replica, the target feature service(s) must have bi-directional synchronization enabled. Feature service layers from a branch versioned feature service must be connected to the default version.
At the conclusion of GenerateReplica, layers that were sourced on the target feature service(s), whose data was/were replicated, are re-sourced to point to the local copy of the geodatabase(s) created via the GenerateReplica process. The extent of data copied to the local geodatabase is controlled by the replicaParams.Extent property.
Calling GenerateReplicas on a map with no sync-enabled content will throw a . See
member.param: The map whose content will be replicated
The parameters used to configure the replication process
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Map cannot be null
Extent cannot be null or empty
Map and extent spatial references must be equal
Map has no sync-enabled content

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.SynchronizeReplicas(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map)
member.summary: Performs a bi-directional sync between all replica content in the map. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Calling SynchronizeReplicas on a map with no syncable content will throw a .
Unsaved edits will not be sync'd. Unsaved edits should be saved or discarded before calling SynchronizeReplicas. Sync'd edits returned from the service by SynchronizeReplicas are not undo-able.
member.param: The map whose content will be sync'd
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Map cannot be null
Map has no syncable content

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.GetCanRemoveReplicas(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map)
member.summary: Gets whether the map contains local syncable content that can be unregistered with the feature service. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: The function does not check if a local replica has been previously unregistered.
member.param: The map to check for syncable content
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Map cannot be null

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Offline.GenerateOfflineMap.RemoveReplicas(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map)
member.summary: Removes all replicas from the map content. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
RemoveReplicas unregisters the corresponding replicas on the feature service. At the conclusion of RemoveReplicas, the local syncable layers are re-sourced to point back to their original feature service (and not the local content). Any un-sync'd edits present in the local content are lost. Call first to sync any unsync'd edits before calling RemoveReplicas.
If a map contains a local replica that was previously unregistered then attempting to unregister it again is treated as a no-op.
Call to determine if the map has local syncable content. Calling RemoveReplicas on a map with no syncable content will throw a . The local SQLite geodatabase containing the replicas unregistered on the service is not deleted.
member.param: The map whose replicas will be removed.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Map cannot be null
Map has no syncable content

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler
member.summary: Defines how Z values will be handled for input Geometries or their vertices that do not lie within the bounds of the input Surface.
member.remarks:
The default behavior for all overrides of is:
All input geometry vertex Z values are initially reset to as a placeholder for the software when determining which Zs have yet to be successfully calculated.
The Z for each vertex is calculated based on its position relative to the surface.
After attempting to calculate the Z for all vertices, any Zs that are still NaN are considered "missing" and assigned the value of .
There may be situations where you only want to overwrite a particular subset of the input geometry vertex Z values. In this case you can use a combination of the OnlyProcessMissingZs and InputZ parameters to identify the Z values to be processed:
preset the required input geometry vertex Zs to a constant value - double.NaN can work, but there may be some other data-appropriate number.
set the equal to the chosen constant value.
set the value of to true.
Only those input Zs whose value is equal to the value of InputZ (within the precision limits of the spatial reference) will be overwritten. Only those Zs will have a Z value calculated from the surface (or set to the value of OutputZ if they fall outside the surface extent.) See also:

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultOutputZ
member.summary: 0.0 is the default for

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultInputZ
member.summary: double.NaN is the default for

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultOnlyProcessMissingZs
member.summary: false is the default for

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.InputZ
member.summary: Gets and sets the input geometry Z value that is considered to be missing.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.OutputZ
member.summary: Gets and sets the output value that will replace all missing input Z values

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.OnlyProcessMissingZs
member.summary: Gets and sets whether or not all input Z values will be processed, or only the input Z values that are determined to be missing

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Animation
member.summary: Represents the collection of tracks, keyframes and transitions that define an animation for the map.

remarks.para: Animation is the process of creating a collection of sequential images and playing them back quickly to create an illusion of movement. Each image, just like a picture you take with a camera, marks a significant instance in time, and is called a keyframe. In ArcGIS Pro, animations are authored by defining a set of keyframes that the system uses to create interpolated intermediate frames. Animations can interpolate the camera position, map time, map range, and layer visibility and transparency.
An instance of this class is returned from the property and can be used to manipulate the state of the animation by creating, editing and deleting keyframes.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Animation.Tracks
member.summary: Gets and sets the list of tracks in the animation.
member.remarks: A track stores the collection of keyframes whose values and transitions define the interpolated values for each frame of the animation. This property will always return 4 tracks and specifically it will contain one , , and . Each track type stores a corresponding keyframe for that type and is used to animate either the camera position, map time, map range, or layer visibility and transparency. The duration of the animation is equal to the time of the last keyframe in all tracks. The animation is removed from the map by deleting all keyframes in all tracks.

member.summary: Gets and sets the active animation.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BasicFeatureLayer.GetDrawingOutline(System.Int64,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.DrawingOutlineType)
member.summary: Get the outline geometry for the corresponding feature identified by the object id. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
GetDrawingOutline is supported for 2D map views only. The view must be initialized or null will be returned. The returned geometry outline for points, lines, and polygons takes into consideration the current view extent (2D) and current map reference scale. If there is no map reference scale set then the current mapscale is used. For annotation the annotation reference scale is used.
For Polygon and Polyline geometry features the output outline will always be Exact. The outlineType parameter is ignored.
Multipatch geometry type is not supported.
member.param: Object id of the feature to lookup
The viewer whose current reference scale will be used
The type of outline to be generated
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
MapView is null
Unsupported geometry type
GetDrawingOutline supported in 2D only

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BasicFeatureLayer.Search(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RangeExtent,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFloorFilterSettings)
member.summary: Executes a spatial or attribute query to the underlying data source and returns features matching the search criteria. For stream layer, you should call for predictable result. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A query filter or spatial filter to perform spatial search.
A time filter only works if the layer is time enabled.
A range filter only works if the layer is range enabled.
A floor filter filter only works if the layer has a defined floor field.
member.returns: A RowCursor (you can cast it to FeatureCursor) allows access to the matched features.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
A geodatabase-related exception has occurred.

remarks.para:
If there is a definition query set on the feature layer, the Search() method will automatically work on the subset of features in the feature layer that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the feature layer's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the feature layer has any joins, this Search() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update features.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.
For stream layers, especially with high velocity real-time updates, features might get expired (removed) while you are looping through feature cursor.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BasicFeatureLayer.Select(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SelectionCombinationMethod,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RangeExtent,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFloorFilterSettings)
member.summary: Selects features based upon the specified attribute and/or spatial criteria and combination method. For stream layer, you should call for predictable result. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A query filter or spatial filter to perform spatial search.
A combination method.
A time filter only works if the layer is time enabled.
A range filter only works if the layer is range enabled.
A floor filter filter only works if the layer has a defined floor field.
member.returns: A selection set.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
Features are highlighted on the map and on the table view as a result of this method call.
If there is a definition query set on the feature layer, the Select() method will automatically work on the subset of features in the feature layer that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the feature layer's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the feature layer has any joins, this Select() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update features.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.
For stream layers, especially with high velocity real-time updates, features might get expired (removed) from the selection set.

member.summary: Sets the where clause of the active definition query. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A where clause that conforms to SQL standard to filter records.
member.returns: A object.
member.exception: This method cannot be called if the feature layer is a member of SubtypeGroupLayer. Use the IsSubtypeLayer property to determine if the feature layer is a member of a SubtypeGroupLayer.
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: If the is null or empty string, then the active query definition is removed and the layer no longer has an active definition query.
Where there is an active definition query, this function updates the where clause of tha definition query with the you pass in.

If the is non-null, and there is no active definition query, a new definition query with the specified where clause is created and becomes the active definition query. An auto generated name gets assigned. All other definition queries that are not active remain unchanged.
Use to activate or deactive any existing definition query.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Bookmark
member.summary: Represents a geographic location in the map. This location can also contain a specific point in time.

remarks.para: Bookmarks can be spatial (2D or 3D) and temporal. If your map is time-enabled, bookmarks can be created for a specific point in time. Bookmarks in an ArcGIS Pro project are associated and managed with the map they were created in. Bookmarks are transferable, so you can re-use bookmarks between multiple maps and scenes in your project, as well as with or without temporal information.

You can call the method on the to return a collection of bookmarks for the map. An similar extension method, , is available off of Project which will return all the bookmarks in the Project. You can use the bookmark to navigate the view by calling the or methods on the .

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FilterBlockDefinition
member.summary: Represents a building scene layer filter block.
member.remarks:
Each building scene layer can contain up to two blocks:
o One that renders the building as a solid (FilterBlockMode == Object3DRenderingMode.None)
o One that renders the building as a wireframe (FilterBlockMode == Object3DRenderingMode.Wireframe)

member.summary: Determines if the filter definition is valid.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BuildingSceneLayer
member.summary: Class to represent the 3D model aspect of Building Information Modeling (BIM).
member.remarks:
BuildingSceneLayers are typically derived from BIM data extracted from Autodesk revit files.
BuildingSceneLayers are a . They contain two top-level child layers:
o A providing an "Overview" (think of it as a simplified rendering of the building exterior).
o A providing the "Full Model" which includes all of the building disciplines extracted from the original BIM.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BuildingDisciplineSceneLayer
member.summary: BuildingDisciplineSceneLayer are sublayers of a .
member.remarks:
BuildingDisciplineSceneLayers represent each of the individual disciplines (architectural, structural, MEP, etc) that are contained within the building and which were derived from the original BIM data used to create the "parent" BuildingScenelayer
BuildingDisciplineSceneLayers are never created, or exist, stand-alone. They have a composite relationship with the BuildingScenelayer which contains them.
A is actually applied to the underlying BuildingDisciplineSceneLayers content (within the special "Full Model" BuildingDisciplineSceneLayer)

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CatalogLayer.SetDefinitionQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the where clause of the active definition query. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A where clause that conforms to SQL standard to filter records.
member.remarks:
Use to activate or deactive any existing definition query.
If the is null or empty string, then the active query definition is removed and the layer no longer has an active definition query.
Where there is an active definition query, this function updates the where clause of the definition query with the you pass in.
If the is non-null, and there is no active definition query, a new definition query with the specified where clause is created and becomes the active definition query. An auto generated name gets assigned. All other definition queries that are not active remain unchanged.
member.returns: A object.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GroupLayer.CanAddSymbolLayerDrawing
member.summary: Determine whether the group layer can have Symbol Layer Drawing added to its definition. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Symbol Layer Drawing, SLD, can be added to a group layer to control all the drawing of its child feature layers collectively. Child feature layers with unclassed symbols, proportional symbols, dictionary symbology, or for polygon feature layers with graduated symbols cannot participate in SLD. The group layer must have at least one child feature layer that can support SLD or CanAddSymbolLayerDrawing() will return false. CanAddSymbolLayerDrawing() will also return false if the input group layer already has SLD added (unless the SLD is invalid) or if the group layer is a child of a parent group layer that has SLD added. When SLD has been established on a parent group layer, it cannot be set for individual child group layers nor other feature layers within the group; all SLD control is set through the parent group layer.
SLD is not available for 3D layers. It can only be set on group layers in a map or in the 2D Layers category of a scene.
member.returns: True if SLD can be added to the group layer
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GroupLayer.HasSymbolLayerDrawingAdded
member.summary: Determine whether the group layer has Symbol Layer Drawing added. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The tuple returns two values (addedOnLayer, addedOnParent). If a group layer has SLD added then tuple.addedOnLayer will be true. If the group layer is the child of a parent group layer that has SLD added then tuple.addedOnLayer will be false and tuple.addedOnParent will be true. If a group layer, or a parent group layer, had SLD added but it contains invalid identifiers on the symbol layers then HasSymbolLayerDrawingAdded() will return false (for the respective tuple value(s)).
Use to determine if a group layer can have Symbol Layer Drawing, SLD, added.
member.returns: Returns a tuple (addedOnLayer, addedOnParent). addedOnLayer will be True if the group layer has SLD added. addedOnParent will be true if the group layer is participating in SLD controlled by a parent group layer with SLD added.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GroupLayer.AddSymbolLayerDrawing
member.summary: Add Symbol Layer Drawing, SLD, to the group layer. After adding SLD it will be enabled. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Use to determine if the group layer can have SLD added. If SLD cannot be added an will be thrown.
Note: Adding SLD to a group layer will set any feature layers within the group that already had SLD added back to their default settings.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
SLD cannot be added to this layer

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GroupLayer.SetUseSymbolLayerDrawing(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets whether Symbol Layer Drawing will be used on the group layer or not. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: Set to true to use symbol layer drawing
member.remarks: Calling SetUseSymbolLayerDrawing(useSLD) on a group layer that does not have SLD added, or on a group layer that is part of a parent group layer using SLD, will throw an . Use to determine if the group layer has SLD added or participates in a parent group layer with SLD added.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
SLD has not been added to this layer or a parent
SLD is being controlled by a parent group layer

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GroupLayer.GetUseSymbolLayerDrawing
member.summary: Gets whether the group layer is currently using Symbol Layer Drawing or not. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Calling GetUseSymbolLayerDrawing() on a group layer that does not have SLD added or SLD added to a parent group layer will throw an . Use to determine if the group layer has SLD added.
The tuple returns two values (useOnLayer, useOnParent). useOnLayer will always be false for a group layer that participates in a parent group layer using SLD. The parent group layer will control SLD for all participating child group layers and feature layers.
member.returns: Returns a tuple(useOnLayer, useOnParent). useOnLayer will be true if the feature layer is currently using SLD. useOnParent will be true if a parent group layer is currently using SLD (and useOnLayer will be false).
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
SLD has not been added to this layer or a parent

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.KnowledgeGraphLayer
member.summary: A knowledge graph layer is a composite layer with a knowledge graph as its data source.
member.remarks:
The knowledge graph layer contains knowledge graph feature layers and knowledge graph tables. One knowledge graph feature layer is created within the knowledge graph composite layer per entity and relationship type when the entity and relationship instances can have spatial features. A standalone table is created within the knowledge graph composite layer per entity and relationship type that is nonspatial.
The underlying knowledge graph datasource can be accessed off any of the child entity and relationship featurelayers and/or standalone tables.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IDisplayTable.Search(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RangeExtent,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFloorFilterSettings)
member.summary: Executes a query to the underlying data source and returns rows matching the search criteria. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A floor filter filter only works if the layer has a defined floor field.
member.returns: A RowCursor allows access to the matched rows.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
If there is a definition query set on the MapMember, the Search() method will automatically work on the subset of rows in the MapMember that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the MapMember's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the MapMember has any joins, this Search() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update rows.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.

member.remarks: If set to true, the element is placed above the reference element. The reference element can either be at the root level of the layout TOC or an element in a group element. Elements can be easily moved into or out of groups.
member.exception: This method must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IElement.IsExpandedInTOC

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IElement.ConvertToGraphics
member.summary: Convert the element to graphics. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.exception: This method must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
If the element cannot be converted then null is returned. Refer to
. The element is removed from the layout and the new graphic elements are added in its place.
member.returns: The list result will contain just one, selected GroupElement that contains all the individual element within it.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis
member.summary: The abstract base class for all Exploratory Analysis types. Used to create a manage a common collection of all Exploratory Analysis objects.

remarks.para: 3D Exploratory Analysis is a suite of interactive tools for performing various forms of quick investigation by interactively creating graphics and editing analysis parameters on-the-fly. Real-time visual feedback is provided in the scene.

A collection of existing Exploratory Analysis objects can be queried with which returns a collection of ExploratoryAnalysisBase objects. You can cast each object to its appropriate subclass to work with it.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.#ctor
member.summary: Base class constructor

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.ID
member.summary:
Identifier for the exploratory analysis object within its current MapView.
The ID is only unique to the map view that it was added to. For this reason, the same instance should not be added to more than one MapView. Use the subclass's copy constructor for that.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.MapView
member.summary: The current MapView that this exploratory analysis object is in.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome
member.summary:
View domes are used to conduct visibility analysis as a sphere extending out from an observer point. A sphere is created representing the visiblity extent. The sphere is painted to represent that parts of the sphere that are visible to the observer or obstructed.
View domes can be used to model real-world objects such as a viewing platform or a radar station.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default ViewDome constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome)
member.summary: Copy constructor. Useful creating a duplicate ViewDome to use in another MapView.
member.param: The ViewDome object to copy

member.summary:

member.summary:

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Viewshed
member.summary:
Viewsheds are used to conduct visibility analysis within a view frustrum of an observer point. A wireframe of the view frustum is is created and geomtry within the frustrum is tinted to represent the features visible to the observer or obstructed.
Viewsheds can be used to model real-world objects like cameras, human patrol agents, or radar stations.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Viewshed.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default Viewshed constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position, heading, and pitch of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
The observer's vertical field of view angle in degrees. Valid values: 0-180.
The observer's horizontal field of view angle in degrees. Valid values: 0-360
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSight
member.summary:
LineOfSight are used to conduct visibility analysis for direct lines from an observer point to one or more targets.
An observer and one or more targets are created with lines connecting the target(s) to the observer. The line segements and targets are painted using the Visible and NotVisible colors if they can be seen by the observer of if the view is obstructed.
Lines of sight can be used to model real-world objects like visibility to points of interest or rough approximations for projectile trajectories.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSight.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera},System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default LineOfSight constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
A list of Camera objects used for the target points. At least one target is required. Must be in the target map's .
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

summary.para: SliceCylinder objects are used to cut away geometry in the scene to reveal hidden or obstructed data to get new perspectives of your 3D data.
SliceCylinder objects are well-suited for define temporary extents to reduce the amount of data on-screen. They can be used to model real-world scenarios like noise propagation from a highway.

Passing FeatureRendererTarget.PreviousObservations or FeatureRendererTarget.TrackLines for a non-track aware layer (feature or stream) will throw a . If the feature layer is a member of a SubtypeGroupLayer and is in the 3D category of the table of contents in a 3D view, the renderer argument passed cannot be of type CIMDotDensityRenderer or you will get a . Use the property to determine if the feature layer is a member of a SubtypeGroupLayer. Use the property to determine if the feature layer is in 3D category of the table of contents.
member.param: Your custom renderer that will be used to draw features of the feature layer.
A indicating the intended usage of the resulting renderer.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer.RecalculateRenderer(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the renderer based on updated values from the data source. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: Indicates whether all the unique values should be generated. Setting this flag to false will generate only the first hundred unique values, if the dataset has that many.
Indicates whether to preserve the existing symbology or not (optional). Default value is true.
member.remarks:
If a new unique value is added to the underlying FeatureClass, in case of a unique value renderer, it gets updated with the newly added value. Similarly with class breaks renderer, RecalculateRenderer tries best to preserve the number of class breaks and recalculates the break values based on the updated values.
Calling RecalculateRenderer on a layer with a unique value renderer or class breaks renderer that has a null color ramp (check the renderer's ColorRamp property via the CIM) will throw a .
Note: Set generateAllUniqueValues = false to restrict the number of regenerated values to be limited to the first 100. This is a useful optimization for those cases where a renderer may contain 100s or 1000s of unique values that would otherwise be regenerated.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Error HRESULT {0} has been returned from a call to a COM component

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer.LookupSymbol(System.Int64,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapView)
member.summary: Looks up the symbol for the corresponding feature identified by the object id. This method will return null when the input OID is not part of the feature layer definition or if the renderer returns a null symbol. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The looked up symbol takes into consideration the current view extent (2D) or camera distance from the ground (3D) and reference scale. Visual variables present on the renderer for color, size*, transparency, and rotation are applied.
Not all renderers support symbol lookup. Check to determine if the given feature layer renderer can support symbol lookup. Calling LookupSymbol on a layer with an unsupported renderer will throw a
*Size visual variable with 3D views is currently assumed to be proportional on all symbol axis.
member.param: Object id of the feature to lookup
The viewer whose scale or camera will be used
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
MapView is null
Unsupported renderer type

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer.CanAddSymbolLayerDrawing
member.summary: Determine whether the feature layer can have Symbol Layer Drawing added to its definition. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Symbol Layer Drawing, SLD, cannot be set/added for layers with unclassed symbols, proportional symbols, dictionary symbology, or for polygon feature layers with graduated symbols. CanAddSymbolLayerDrawing() will also return false if the input layer already has SLD added (unless the SLD is invalid) or is a child of a group layer that has SLD added. When SLD has been established for a group layer, it cannot be set for individual layers within the group; all SLD control is set through the parent group layer.
SLD is not available for 3D layers. It can only be set on feature layers in a map or in the 2D Layers category of a scene.
member.returns: True if SLD can be added to the feature layer
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer.HasSymbolLayerDrawingAdded
member.summary: Determine whether the feature layer or a parent group layer has Symbol Layer Drawing added. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The tuple returns two values (addedOnLayer, addedOnParent). If the feature layer has SLD added then tuple.addedOnLayer will be true. If the feature layer is part of a group layer that has SLD added then tuple.addedOnLayer will be false and tuple.addedOnParent will be true. If a layer, or parent group layer, had SLD added but but it contains invalid identifiers on the symbol layers then HasSymbolLayerDrawingAdded() will return false for the respective tuple value(s).
Use to determine if a feature layer can have Symbol Layer Drawing, SLD, added.
member.returns: Returns a tuple (addedOnLayer, addedOnParent). addedOnLayer will be True if the feature layer has SLD added. addedOnParent will be true if the feature layer is participating in SLD controlled by a parent group layer with SLD added.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.remarks: Use to determine if the feature layer can have SLD added. If SLD cannot be added an will be thrown.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer.GetUseSymbolLayerDrawing
member.summary: Gets whether the layer or a parent group layer is currently using Symbol Layer Drawing or not. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Calling GetUseSymbolLayerDrawing() on a feature layer that does not have SLD added or SLD added to a parent group layer will throw an . Use to determine if the feature layer has SLD added.
The tuple returns two values (useOnLayer, useOnParent). useOnLayer will always be false for a feature layer that participates in a group layer using SLD. The group layer will control SLD for all participating child feature layers.
member.returns: Returns a tuple(useOnLayer, useOnParent). useOnLayer will be true if the feature layer is currently using SLD. useOnParent will be true if a parent group layer is currently using SLD (and useOnLayer will be false).
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
SLD has not been added to this layer or a parent

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureSceneLayer.Select(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SelectionCombinationMethod)
member.summary: Selects features based upon the specified attribute and/or spatial criteria and combination method. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A query filter or spatial filter

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Keyframe
member.summary: Represents the base class for all keyframe types.

remarks.para: A keyframe is a visual way-point along the animation path in a map or scene. When an animation is played, values such as the location of the camera, the current map time, the current map range, and layer transparencies are interpolated between the stored states defined by the keyframe using a configurable transition type. The transition type defines how frames are interpolated between keyframes.

For example, let's say we have 2 keyframes in a track one at a time of 0 seconds and the second at a time of 3 seconds. The first keyframe has a value for X of 1 and the second keyframe has a value for X of 5. The second keyframe defines the transition for X as linear. What this means is at 0 seconds in the animation X is 1, at 3 seconds X is 5 and at 1.5 seconds or halfway between the value would be 3. Each keyframe may have one or more values it stores and a corresponding transition definition for each value.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Keyframe.#ctor(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMViewKeyframe,System.Action,System.Action{ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Keyframe,System.Double})
member.summary: Internal constructor so that external code cannot derive from the class.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Keyframe.TrackTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of time that the keyframe exists in the track.
member.remarks: If the time is set to the same time as another keyframe in the same track the keframe will be overwritten. The time is rounded to the nearest millisecond.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CameraKeyframe
member.summary: Represents a keyframe in the .
member.remarks: The camera keyframe stores the value of the camera and defines the transitions for each of the values of the camera.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CameraKeyframe.TransitionScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating the shape of the curve for adjustable transitions. The value must be between 0.0 and 1.0. Smaller values will result in a tighter / smaller curve than larger values.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CameraKeyframe.TransitionMode

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType
member.summary: Layer cache type. Use with to control layer caching options.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType.None
member.summary: Don't cache the layer locally. If the layer supports feature caching (i.e. is a feature service layer), then any existing cache is also cleared.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType.Session
member.summary: Cache will be cleared when the session ends.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType.MaxAge
member.summary: Cache will be kept between sessions and cleared every minutes. Use SetDisplayCacheMaxAge to set the cache age. Not supported for layers that support feature caching (i.e. feature service layers).

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType.Permanent
member.summary: Cache will be kept between sessions and invalidated when the data is updated. Not supported for layers that support feature caching (i.e. feature service layers).

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Layer.SetDisplayCacheMaxAge(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the duration after which the layer's display cache will be refreshed in the local storage. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Only applies when = otherwise it is ignored.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Layer.SetCacheOptions(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LayerCacheType)
member.summary: Sets the layer's caching options. If the layer's feature class supports feature caching, then both the display cache and feature cache are set otherwise just the display cache is set. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run
member.param: The cache type.
member.remarks:
The caching options are as follows
None - Don't cache the layer locally. If the layer supports feature caching (i.e. is a feature service layer), then any existing cache is also cleared.
Session - Cache will be cleared when the session ends.
MaxAge - Cache will be kept between sessions and cleared every minutes. If the layer supports feature caching (i.e. is a feature service layer), then this caching option is not supported and no changes are made.
Permanent - Cache will be kept between sessions and invalidated when the data is updated. If the layer supports feature caching (i.e. is a feature service layer), then this caching option is not supported and no changes are made.
Refer to the Pro help for more information on caching: How caching works.
Note: for feature services only and are supported. For branch versioned feature services, caching is managed by the application automatically and is set to DisplayCacheType.InSession.
Attempting to set a cache type on a layer that is not supported is ignored. Note: If setting LayerCacheType.MaxAge, call SetDisplayCacheMaxAge to set the duration otherwise it uses the default value that is 5.0 minutes.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.summary: Specifies the layer or standalone table be added at a position best suited to its type.

member.summary: Specifies the layer or standalone table be added to the top of the container.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapMemberPosition.AddToBottom
member.summary: Specifies the layer or standalone table be added to the bottom of the container.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapMemberPosition.Index
member.summary: Specifies the layer or standalone table be added based on the MapMemberIndex property.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer
member.summary: Provides read-only access to layers inside the layer container.
member.remarks: A layer container could be a map, a group layer or a composite layer that implements ILayerContainer

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer.Layers
member.summary: Gets a read-only collection of layers from the container.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer.GetLayersAsFlattenedList
member.summary: Returns a read only flat list of layers where nested groups are not preserved.
member.returns: A read only list of layers

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer.FindLayer(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a layer using a URI.
member.param: The URI of the layer. Which is unique identifier for each layer
(optional) When true the search continues in group layers. (default value = true)
member.returns: A Layer

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer.FindLayers(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds layers by name.
member.param: Name of the layer
(optional) When true the search continues in group layers. (default value = true)
member.returns: A Layer

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainer.GetSnapshot
member.summary: Returns a read-only snapshot of the layers in the container.
member.remarks: Prefer this function over direct access to the Layers collection, especially if you're on the GUI thread. Layer collections are modified on the worker thread, so using this function will ensure proper synchronization.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ILayerContainerEdit
member.summary: Provides access to layers inside the layer container to modify

member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map
member.summary: Represents the primary object used for the organization of geographic data.

remarks.para: To create a Map, you must call one of the create methods of the MapFactory class.
To open a map, use ProApp.Panes.CreateMapPaneAsync method.

You can also think of a Map as a container of layers, StandaloneTables, bookmarks etc. You need to use a MapView to interact with a map. Multiple MapViews can be opened for a Map at a given time, but there can only be one active MapView which is returned by the MapView.Active static member. Use the Map property to access the Map object associated with the MapView. The Map object has properties that operate on all layers within the map, such as spatial reference, reference scale, and so on, along with methods that manipulate the map's layers.
