member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map.CanFillFeatureCache
member.summary: Determines whether a fill feature cache operation can be executed. Only one fill feature cache operation can be exxecuted at any one time.
member.remarks: You should use this function before calling or to ensure that an existing fill feature cache operation is not already in progress.
member.returns: True if the cache can be filled. False if an existing fill cache operation is in progress.

members.member:
The feature cache is filled for all visible web feature layers (feature services) in the map. A fill feature cache operation can be started by clicking the 'Fill' button on the ribbon or by executing the or API methods.
Fills the feature cache for all visible web feature layers (feature services) in the map.
Use before calling this function to ensure than an existing fill feature cache operation is not already in progress.
Show toast notifications when the cache operation is started and completed.
Filling the feature cache is only allowed on the active map. The fill feature cache operation cannot be executed - likely another fill cache operation is in progress.

member.param: A Datastore that you want to find and be replaced with the replaceDatabaseStore parameter depending on the value of the validate parameter.
A Datastore that you want to replace to.

(Optional) -true- the workspace will only be updated if the replaceDatabaseStore value is a valid workspace. If it is not valid, the workspace will not be replaced.
-false- the method will set the workspace to match the replaceDatabaseStore, regardless of a valid match. In this case, if a match does not exist, then layers and standalone tables would appear broken.
(default value = true)

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map.SaveAsWebMapFile(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Save the current map to webmap file format. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: The fullpath of the webmap file to save to
The url of the portal to use for compatibility
Use symbology compatible with all web map clients
member.remarks:
Only webmap compatible layers will be saved out to the specified file. The current version of the specified portal will be used to determine webmap compatibility. If null or empty string is passed as the url for the portal, it will default to arcgis online. If a url for a portal not in the list of portals for the current user is provided, it will default to arcgis online.
Set UseCompatibleSymbols to true to convert layer symbology to symbology compatible for use with all web map clients. False (default) uses the existing ArcGIS Pro symbology when publishing the web map which may or may not be compatible with all web map clients.
A suffix of ".json" will be appended to the filename if no suffix or a different suffix is provided. If the specified filename exists it will be overwritten
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Directory does not exist
The value of webMapFileName cannot be null

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapMember.GetDataTimeExtent(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the time extent of the data for the specified fieldName - that is the minimum and maximum dates present in the data. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Use this method to retrieve the minimum and maximum dates for a specific field. It calculates the full time extent using all the rows in the table. If the returned time extent is empty, it likely means that the time field did not contain any valid time stamps in a supported time format. The time extent returned can be used to set a time filter on the mapMember via the method.

member.summary: Gets the set of time intervals for the specified field name present in the data. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Use this method on datasets where the data was captured at irregular intervals - such as earthquakes or power outages. The values returned are the data capture intervals for the rows. MapMembers that have a time filter with a of use these same time interval values to filter the data in the UI.

member.summary: Gets the line of sight components. This method was written for TIN, terrain, LAS and raster layers; it appears here because it was also implemented for IInternalRasterLayer. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PopupContent.IsDynamicContent
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the content for the pop-up should be created the first time it is loaded in the window.
member.remarks: Use this option if you want to create the content for the pop-up dynamically when the item is displayed in the window. This is useful if you are going to be showing multiple items in the pop-up window and don't want to generate the content for the item until it is viewed in the window. To take advantage of this dynamic content creation you must derive from the PopupContent class and override the method. This method will be called the first time the content for the item is requested.

Raster layers do not support field based time parameters; that is filtering based on attribute values. They also do not suport , or when only start or end dates are specified.
member.param: The time parameters to set.
member.returns: True if the mapMember supports time filtering and the are valid. False otherwise.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RasterLayer.CanGetLineOfSight(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams)
member.summary: Determines whether a Line of Sight analysis can be calculated for the given set of parameters. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A set of parameters that will be used to calculate the Line of Sight.
member.remarks:
It is important to call this method prior to to ensure that a possible result can be found given the set of input parameters. In addition to checking for valid observer and target points (that is they have x,y coordinates) and non NaN observer height, target height and refraction factors, the observer and target points must also lie within the extent of the surface's area. this method also checks for a 3D Analyst license which is required to perform the analysis. Finally if or are set to true, then the spatial reference of the surface needs to be in a projected coordinate system and have Z coordinate units defined.
Note that if this method returns true it does not preclude the method from throwing an exception due to a calculation error and callers should code defensively and use appropriate exception handling.
member.returns: True if checks pass. False otherwise.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RasterLayer.GetLineOfSight(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams)
member.summary: Performs a line of sight analysis for an observer and target point on the surface. Determines if the target point is visible from a given observer point. This method requires a 3D Analyst license. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
See the following links for more information about Line of Sight analysis - https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/3d-analyst/line-of-sight.htm and https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/3d-analyst/how-line-of-sight-works.htm. Note that the geoprocessing tool uses a feature class of lines for the observer and target inputs whereas this method performs the calculation on a single pair of MapPoints only.
Use to determine if the set of input parameters is valid prior to calling this method.
The elevation of the observer point (let's call it observerZ) is derived as follows. If you provide a Z-aware (3D) observer point, observerZ will be set to its Z value; if you provide a 2D observer point, then observerZ will be set to the Z value of the surface at the XY of the observer point. If you specify an observer height offset, it will be added to observerZ. Similarly with the target point for calculating targetZ.
GetLineOfSight doesn't always produce all possible results. Internally the function generates an imaginary straight 3D line (the sight line) from the observer point (at observerZ) to the target point (at targetZ). It then interpolates (drapes) this line onto the surface, creating an imaginary profile line. The typical results consist of a "visible" line (possibly a multipart line) representing the portion of the profile line which is visible from the observer point (at observerZ), and an "invisible" line (possibly a multipart line) representing the portion of the profile line which is not visible from the observer point (at observerZ). If the sight line intersects the surface at least once, then an obstruction point is created at the first intersection point which is closest to the observer point.The obstruction point, if one is created, will always lie along the profile line, but will typically not occur at the end of the first visible line part.
member.param: The object which contains all input values.
member.returns: A instance.
member.exception: cannot be null.
A 3D Analyst license is required.
The set of parameters is invalid for this surface. See .
An exception occurred within the Line of Sight calculation.
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RasterLayer.ArcGIS#Desktop#Internal#Mapping#IInternalRasterLayer#GetLineOfSightInternal(ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.LineOfSightParamsInternal)
member.summary: Gets the line of sight components. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: The user should pass either one line feature layer (from which the observer and target points will be derived by using the first line), or a pair of points (observer and target). Refer to the help documentation of the Line of Sight geoprocessing tool for more information.
member.param: The object which contains all necessary values.
member.returns: A LineOfSightResultInternal instance.
member.exception: A 3D Analyst license is required.
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents an abstract class definition for all types of renderers.
member.remarks:
RendererDefinition classes allow you to define parameters to create renderers to draw features with simple renderer or based on unique values or the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
Once you define a renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents an abstract class definition for class breaks renderers.
member.remarks:
ClassBreaksRendererDefinition defines the parameters for drawing features based on the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
To set up a ClassBreaksRenderer you first need to know how many classes you will have. Then you specify a particular classification algorithm (e.g. natural breaks, quantile, equal interval) to your data to compute class breaks for your renderer. You also provide the color ramp. Once you define a renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.ClassificationField
member.summary: Gets or sets field name used in the renderer. This is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.ClassificationMethod
member.summary: Gets and sets classification method to be used to compute class breaks. This is required. The default value is .

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.BreakCount
member.summary: Gets or sets number of desired class breaks. The default value is 5.
member.remarks: Optional, it does not apply when StandardDeviation or DefinedInterval is used as the classification method.

member.summary: Gets or set standard deviation interval.
member.remarks: Only applicable when ClassifcationMethod is StandardDeviation.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.DotDensityRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents a dot density symbol renderer definition to show quantitative values for a field as a series of pattern fills based on the field value for each polygon.
member.remarks: With dot density symbology, the data you symbolize is not classified. Instead, quantitative values for one or more fields are represented as a collection of point symbols (typically solid circles or dots) within each polygon. Each dot represents a constant number of things, or people, or other quantifiable phenomena. The dots are equally sized, even when multiple fields are symbolized together within a layer.

member.remarks: Default value is 2.

member.remarks: Default value is 1.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ChartRendererDefinition
member.summary: Abstract base class for the different chart renderer definitions.
member.remarks: Chart symbology is most effective when mapping no more than 30 features in a 2D map. When you have more than 30 features, patterns on the map become difficult to determine.

member.summary: Gets or sets the color ramp be used to pick color for the charts from.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StackedChartRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents a stacked chart renderer definition to display amounts by category. Each feature is annotated with a chart that shows the amounts present in each category.
member.remarks: Default orientation is vertical or "column"

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StackedChartRendererDefinition.StackWidth
member.summary: Gets and sets the width of the stack chart in pts

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StackedChartRendererDefinition.SizeOption
member.summary: Gets and sets the stack chart size option
member.remarks:
Determines how the length of the overall stack chart symbol is set. Size can be either fixed (all the stacks the same length) which is the default or proportional. If it is proportional, length will be based on the sum of all (eligible) fields:
The default value is .

member.summary: Gets and sets the length of the stack chart in pts

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PieChartRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents a pie chart renderer definition to show indivudal amounts by category by their relative proportion (to the total of all amounts).
member.remarks: Pie charts are most effective when there are only a few categories

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PieChartRendererDefinition.SizeOption
member.summary: Gets and sets the pie chart size option
member.remarks:
Determines how the size of the overall pie chart symbol is set. Size can be either fixed: , default, (all the same size) or proportional. If it is proportional, it is based either on the value of a particular field: or the sum of all (eligible) fields:
For a value of , specifiy the name of the field to use in otherwise the first eligible field will be used.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PieChartRendererDefinition.FixedSize
member.summary: Gets and sets the fixed size in points (pt).
member.remarks: Corresponds to a of otherwise it is ignored

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PieChartRendererDefinition.FieldName
member.summary: Gets and sets the field name to use in determining the overall size of the pie chart (per feature)
member.remarks: Corresponds to SizeOption of PieChartSizeOptions.Field otherwise it is ignored. If FieldName is not specified for PieChartSizeOptions.Field then the first eligible field in the underlying dataset is used.

member.summary: Create a HeatMapRendererDefinition.
member.param: (Optional) Controls the color scheme of the heat map. If no color scheme is specified, a default color ramp will be used.
(Optional) Controls how far the heat spreads away from the points.
(Optional) Controls the pixilation of the raster. This is an arbitrary range that goes from Best (10) to Fastest (0).
(Optional) Used in the legend to denote the maximum value in the color scheme.
(Optional) Used in the legend to denote the minimum value in the color scheme.
member.remarks: Only applicable for point feature layers.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.HeatMapRendererDefinition.#ctor(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMColorRamp,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String)

(Optional) Controls the pixilation of the raster. This is an arbitrary range that goes from Best (10) to Fastest (0).
(Optional) Used in the legend to denote the maximum value in the color scheme.
(Optional) Used in the legend to denote the minimum value in the color scheme.
member.remarks: Only applicable for point feature layers.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UnclassedColorsRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents an unclassed colors renderer definition to show qualitative differences in feature values with an evenly distributed color scheme.

remarks.para: Unclassed colors symbology is similar to graduated colors in that it's used to make choropleth maps.
Once you define an unclassed renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudRendererDefinition
member.summary: A point cloud renderer definition for creating a .
member.remarks:
Convert a point cloud renderer definition to a CIMPointCloudRenderer using the method.
Use to check whether or not a point cloud layer contains (one of) the necessary field(s) to support the given renderer. There are up to five fields that could be available for rendering depending on the given layer:
1. ELEVATION: can be used with Stretch and ClassBreaks
2. CLASS_CODE: LAS classification codes, can be used with Unique Value
3. RETURNS: Lidar pulse return number, can be used with Unique Value
4. RGB: can be used with RGB
5. INTENSITY: can be used with Stretch and ClassBreaks

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudRendererDefinition.RendererType
member.summary: Gets or sets the renderer type.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudRendererDefinition.Field
member.summary: Gets or sets the field whose values will be used by the renderer.
member.remarks:
The specified field must:
o Match the provided renderer type
o Be present on the point cloud scene layer

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StandaloneTable
member.summary: Represents a table without geometries that can be added to your map.
member.remarks: It can be used in conjunction with the layers. The data in a StandaloneTable does not display in your map, but is listed in the table of contents. You can work with this data as you would work with any tabular information of geographic features. For example, you can view the table, add new fields, create graphs, and join it to other tables or layers.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StandaloneTable.Search(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RangeExtent,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFloorFilterSettings)
member.summary: Executes a query to the underlying data source and returns rows matching the search criteria. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A time filter only works if the table is time enabled.
A range filter only works if the table is range enabled.
A floor filter filter only works if the layer has a defined floor field.
member.returns: A RowCursor allows access to the matched rows.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
If there is a definition query set on the standalone table, the Search() method will automatically work on the subset of rows in the standalone table that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the standalone table's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the standalone table has any joins, this Search() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update rows.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StandaloneTable.Select(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SelectionCombinationMethod,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RangeExtent,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFloorFilterSettings)

A floor filter filter only works if the layer has a defined floor field.
member.returns: A selection set.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
Rows in the standalone table view are highlighted as a result of this method call.
If there is a definition query set on the standalone table, the Select() method will automatically work on the subset of rows in the standalone table that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the standalone table's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the standalone table has any joins, this Select() method takes that into account.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.

member.remarks: If the is null or empty string, then the active query definition is removed and the layer no longer has an active definition query.
Where there is an active definition query, this function updates the where clause of tha definition query with the you pass in.

If the is non-null, and there is no active definition query, a new definition query with the specified where clause is created and becomes the active definition query. An auto generated name gets assigned. All other definition queries that are not active remain unchanged.
Use to activate or deactive any existing definition query.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer
member.summary: Represents layer with a collection of real-time features and their visual representation.

remarks.para: Stream layer is a type of .To create a StreamLayer, you must call CreateLayer method of the LayerFactory class, instead of directly using a constructor.

When you use , you need to pass in a . You should set and in a only when the source stream service has associated archieved feature service layer. See for details. That is because at the creation time a stream layer starts with empty set of features.
You can call anytime later once you have sufficient features to compute and assign a or to a stream layer.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.GetExpirationMaxAge
member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum age for features. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: When is true, ExpirationMaxAge represents the maximum age within each track. Previous observations older than the maximum expiration age, compared to the latest observation in the same track, will be removed. When is false, features older than the maximum expiration age, comparing to the current time, will get removed.
member.returns: The indicating the ExpirationMaxAge
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum feature count. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: When is true, ExpirationMaxCount represents the maximum number of features that will be stored per track. Otherwise, it represents the maximum number of features.
member.returns: The indicating the ExpirationMaxCount
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.GetExpirationMethod
member.summary: Gets the current expiration method. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SetExpirationMaxAge(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the expiration maximum age for features. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
must be set to or the maximum age is ignored. When is true, ExpirationMaxAge represents the maximum age within each track. Previous observations older than the maximum expiration age, compared to the latest observation in the same track, will be removed. When is false, features older than the maximum expiration age, comparing to the current time, will get removed. The stream layer uses a FIFO method - the first observation in is the first one to be removed and so on. To prevent any features from being removed, set ExpirationMaxAge to 0.
Note: When a stream layer is track-aware, use to set how many previous observations will be displayed on the map. Whereas SetExpirationMaxAge defines how many previous observation will be stored in memory.
member.param: The indicating features older than this value will be removed.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SetExpirationMaxCount(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum feature count. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: The values indicating how many features will be stored at any given time.
member.remarks:
must be set to or the maximum feature count is ignored. When is true, ExpirationMaxCount represents the maximum number of features that will be stored per track. Otherwise, it represents the maximum number of features that will be stored period. The stream layer uses a FIFO method - the first observation in is the first one to be removed and so on. To prevent any features from being removed, set ExpirationMaxCount to 0.
When a stream layer is track-aware, use to set how many will be displayed on the map. Whereas SetExpirationMaxCount defines how many previous observation will be stored in memory.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.Subscribe(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Subscribe to receive row events. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Use to subscribe on any thread. As opposed to , this method does not perform a Search before subscribing. As a consequence, the returned will only iterate over rows that became available immediately after the execution of this method. If no query filter is set, all rows that become available will be retrieved.
member.param: A null query filter will cause all rows that become available to be retrieved.
If set to true, all the entries in will reference the most current row returned by . To ensure all the entries in remain unique, set to false. The default is true.
member.returns: A that encapsulates the retrieved rows, as well as provides facilities to wait for new row events.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream Layer was disconnected from its underlying feature class.
A geodatabase-related exception has occurred.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SearchAndSubscribe(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Searches the table for existing rows using the query criteria and then subscribes to receive row events. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: This operation is atomic. It is guaranteed that the returned will correctly reflect any insert or delete operations that occured at any time during the exection of this method. Use to search and subscribe on any thread. If no query filter is set, all pre-existing rows will be searched and all rows that become available after subscribing will be retrieved.
member.param: A null query filter will search all rows and all rows that become available will be retrieved.
If set to true, all the entries in will reference the most current row returned by . To ensure all the entries in remain unique, set to false. The default is true.
member.returns: A that encapsulates the retrieved rows, as well as provides facilities to wait for new row events.

member.summary: Gets and sets the observer point.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.TargetPoint
member.summary: Gets and sets the target point.
member.remarks: If specified it will be projected to the spatial reference of the surface.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.ObserverHeightOffset
member.summary: Gets and sets the vertical offset to apply to the observer point (in the vertical unit of measure of the surface). Default value is 0.0.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.TargetHeightOffset
member.summary: Gets and sets the vertical offset to apply to the target point (in the vertical unit of measure of the surface). Default value is 0.0.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.ApplyCurvature
member.summary: Gets and sets whether the earth's curvature should be taken into consideration. Default value is false.
member.remarks: The curvature option makes adjustments to take the curvature of the earth into consideration when performing line-of-sight calculations. It can only be used when the spatial reference of the input surface is in a projected coordinate system and z-coordinate units are defined.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.ApplyRefraction
member.summary: Gets and sets whether atmospheric refraction should be taken into consideration. Default value is false.
member.remarks: The refraction option will compensate for the influence of atmospheric refraction, which forces light to bend as it passes through the atmosphere. The amount of this deviation is controlled by variations in air pressure and density, humidity, temperature, and elevation. It can only be used when the surface's spatial reference is in a projected coordinate system and z-coordinate units are defined.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.RefractionFactor
member.summary: Gets and sets the refraction factor to apply. Default value is .
member.remarks: Explicitly set this to zero if no RefractionFactor is desired.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams.OutputSpatialReference
member.summary: Gets and sets the spatial reference which the output features will be projected to. Default value is null. If null, then the output features use the spatial reference of the surface.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightResult
member.summary: A class to contain the results of running
member.remarks: The output line of sight is divided into visible and invisible portions along the input sight line running from the to the .

member.summary: Gets whether the target point is visible from the observer point.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightResult.VisibleLine
member.summary: Gets the visible part(s), if any, of the surface profile, from the perspective of the observer point when looking towards the target point.
member.remarks: VisibleLine can be null - meaning the sight line is totally obstructed. It will be projected to the or the spatial reference of the surface if is null.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightResult.InvisibleLine
member.summary: Gets the invisible part(s), if any, of the surface profile, from the perspective of the observer point when looking towards the target point.
member.remarks: InvisibleLine can be null - meaning there is no obstruction along the sight line. It will be projected to the or the spatial reference of the surface if is null.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightResult.ObstructionPoint
member.summary: Gets the location, if any, of the first obstruction on the observer's sight line to the target.
member.remarks: ObstructionPoint can be null - meaning there is no obstruction along the sight line. It will be projected to the or the spatial reference of the surface if is null.

member.summary: Gets whether the target is visible from the invisible line.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceLayer.CanGetLineOfSight(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams)
member.summary: Determines whether a Line of Sight analysis can be calculated for the given set of parameters. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A set of parameters that will be used to calculate the Line of Sight.
member.remarks:
It is important to call this method prior to to ensure that a possible result can be found given the set of input parameters. In addition to checking for valid observer and target points (that is they have x,y coordinates) and non NaN observer height, target height and refraction factors, the observer and target points must also lie within the extent of the surface's area. this method also checks for a 3D Analyst license which is required to perform the analysis. Finally if or are set to true, then the spatial reference of the surface needs to be in a projected coordinate system and have Z coordinate units defined.
Note that if this method returns true it does not preclude the method from throwing an exception due to a calculation error and callers should code defensively and use appropriate exception handling.
member.returns: True if checks pass. False otherwise.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceLayer.GetLineOfSight(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSightParams)
member.summary: Performs a line of sight analysis for an observer and target point on the surface. Determines if the target point is visible from a given observer point. This method requires a 3D Analyst license. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
See the following links for more information about Line of Sight analysis - https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/3d-analyst/line-of-sight.htm and https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/3d-analyst/how-line-of-sight-works.htm. Note that the geoprocessing tool uses a feature class of lines for the observer and target inputs whereas this method performs the calculation on a single pair of MapPoints only.
Use to determine if the set of input parameters is valid prior to calling this method.
The elevation of the observer point (let's call it observerZ) is derived as follows. If you provide a Z-aware (3D) observer point, observerZ will be set to its Z value; if you provide a 2D observer point, then observerZ will be set to the Z value of the surface at the XY of the observer point. If you specify an observer height offset, it will be added to observerZ. Similarly with the target point for calculating targetZ.
GetLineOfSight doesn't always produce all possible results. Internally the function generates an imaginary straight 3D line (the sight line) from the observer point (at observerZ) to the target point (at targetZ). It then interpolates (drapes) this line onto the surface, creating an imaginary profile line. The typical results consist of a "visible" line (possibly a multipart line) representing the portion of the profile line which is visible from the observer point (at observerZ), and an "invisible" line (possibly a multipart line) representing the portion of the profile line which is not visible from the observer point (at observerZ). If the sight line intersects the surface at least once, then an obstruction point is created at the first intersection point which is closest to the observer point.The obstruction point, if one is created, will always lie along the profile line, but will typically not occur at the end of the first visible line part.
member.param: The object which contains all input values.
member.returns: A instance.
member.exception: cannot be null.
GetLineOfSight is only supported on TIN layers.
A 3D Analyst license is required.
The set of parameters is invalid for this surface. See .
An exception occurred within the Line of Sight calculation.
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.summary: Gets the where clause of the active definition query.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ITableDefinitionQueries.SetDefinitionQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the where clause of the active definition query. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A where clause that conforms to SQL standard to filter records.
member.returns: A object.
member.exception: This method cannot be called if the feature layer is a member of SubtypeGroupLayer. Use the IsSubtypeLayer property to determine if the feature layer is a member of a SubtypeGroupLayer.
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: If the is null or empty string, then the active query definition is removed and the layer no longer has an active definition query.
Where there is an active definition query, this function updates the where clause of tha definition query with the you pass in.

If the is non-null, and there is no active definition query, a new definition query with the specified where clause is created and becomes the active definition query. An auto generated name gets assigned. All other definition queries that are not active remain unchanged.
Use to activate or deactive any existing definition query.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeRange
member.summary: Represents an extent of time defined by a start and an end time.
member.remarks: TimeRange contains two properties and which defines an extent of time. Either property can be set to null. When is null it means the time range begins infinite in the past and when is null this means it ends infinite in the future. This is useful for example when setting the property to show all time before a given date, all time after a given date or to just show all time.

The GetHashCode method provides this hash code for algorithms that need quick checks of object equality.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters
member.summary: Represents a set of properties for describing a time filter assigned to a .
member.remarks:
Achieve a fixed time extent filter by setting the and/or properties.
Achieve a time filter based on a single attribute field by setting the property.
Achieve a time filter for data with both start and end times by setting the and properties.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters.TimeRange
member.summary: Gets and sets the time extent. This consists of a date and an date. member.remarks: Setting this correlates to a feature existing at an instant in time.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters.EndTimeFieldName
member.summary: Gets and sets a second time field name. Use this if features have both start and end times stored in two fields.
member.remarks: Setting this, in conjunection with correlates to a feature existing for a certain duration in time.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters.TimeFormat
member.summary: Gets and sets the time format for the data.
member.remarks: Set this when specifying or and the field type is string or numeric. Determine the best Time Format to use, based on the time stamps in the field. Use to Verify your choice is valid for the field type.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters.IsLiveFeed
member.summary: Gets and set if time data includes continuous updates.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TimeParameters.TimeIntervalType
member.summary: Gets and sets the type of time internval. Default is .
member.remarks:
indicates there is no time interval.
indicates the data was captured at regular intervals, such as hour temperature readings. Use the to get or set the interval value and unit.
indicates the data was captured at irregular intervals, such as earthquakes or power outages. Use the to get or set the field containing the interval values. If more than 1000 values are present, then the TimeIntervalType reverts to .

member.remarks:
TinRendererDefinition classes allow you to define parameters to create renderers to draw faces, edges, nodes, breaklines, and contours.
Once you define a renderer, you can call a surface layer's CanCreateRenderer, CreateRenderer, CanSetRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a surface layer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Track
member.summary: Represents the base class for all track types.
member.remarks: A track stores the collection of keyframes whose values and transitions define the interpolated values for each frame of the animation. The property for the animation always returns 4 tracks: a , a , a and a . Each track type stores a corresponding keyframe for that type and is used to animate either the camera position, map time, map range, or layer visibility and transparency. The duration of the animation is equal to the time of the last keyframe in all tracks. The animation is removed from the map by deleting all keyframes in all tracks.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CameraTrack.CreateKeyframe(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.TimeSpan,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.AnimationTransition)
member.summary: Create a new keyframe.
member.param: The value of the camera.
The time at which to insert the keyframe in the track. In the UI the default is .
The transition for keyframe.
member.remarks: If a keyframe already exists at that time it will be overwritten. The time is rounded to the nearest millisecond. When you create a keyframe the specified transition will be used for all the values of the camera. It is possible to change the transitions for the individual values of the camera by settting the transition for the value on the keyframe./>

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.CameraTrack.CreateKeyframe(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.TimeSpan,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.AnimationTransition,System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new keyframe.
member.param: The value of the camera.
The time at which to insert the keyframe in the track.
The transition for all values of the camera. In the UI the default is .
A value indicating the shape of the curve for adjustable transitions. The value must be between 0.0 and 1.0. Smaller values will result in a tighter / smaller curve than larger values.
member.remarks: If a keyframe already exists at that time it will be overwritten. The time is rounded to the nearest millisecond. When you create a keyframe the specified transition will be used for all the values of the camera. It is possible to change the transitions for the individual values of the camera by settting the transition for the value on the keyframe./>

The value of the transparency.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudFilterDefinition.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32},System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Core.CIM.PointCloudReturnType},System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassFlag})
member.summary: Creates a PointCloudFilterDefinition.
member.remarks: PointCloudFilterDefinition uses classification codes, return values, and classification flags to filter the point cloud data being rendered. Classification codes are used to define the type of surface, or surfaces, that reflected the lidar pulse. Return values correspond to the value stored in the RETURNS field of a point cloud and are typically influenced by the height of each surface that was scanned. Classification flags are a secondary description of the lidar pulses (in addition to their classification code).
member.param: A list of one or more classification codes
A list of one or more return values or null
A list of one or more classification flags or null

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer
member.summary: Point cloud scene layers allow for fast display and consumption of large volumes of point cloud data.
member.remarks: The primary source of point cloud data is usually LAS and lidar data. Lidar surveys for terrain, buildings, forest canopy, roads, bridges, overpasses, and more can make up the point cloud data used for a point cloud scene layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.RendererType
member.summary: Gets the current RendererType

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.IsSnappable
member.summary: Gets whether feature snapping is enabled

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.IsEyeDomeLightingEnabled
member.summary: Gets whether Eye Dome Lighting (EDL) is enabled on the layer.
member.remarks: Eye-Dome Lighting can improve depth perception in a 3D layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.EyeDomeLightingRadius
member.summary: Gets the Eye Dome Lighting (EDL) radius value. The EDL radius controls the width of effects.
member.remarks: The eye dome lighting radius is a value between 1 and 5 inclusive. Ensure that is true for this value to have effect. The default value is 2 pixels wide. Note, that a larger radius will slow down performance.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.EyeDomeLightingStrength
member.summary: Gets the Eye Dome Lighting (EDL) strength value. The EDL strength adjusts the intensity of the resulting effects.
member.remarks: The eye dome lighting strength value is a percentage (that is a value betewen 0 and 100). EDL is disabled when the value is set to 0%. The default value is 50%. A larger value will give you a stronger perception of the depth. Ensure that is true for this value to have effect.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.GetAvailableClassFlagsAndLabels
member.summary: Get the available classification flags and labels. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Classification flag values provide a secondary description of the point cloud data (beyond their classification code). Flags include Synthetic, key-point, withheld, and overlap. Less common are scan direction and edge of flight line. Classification flags are used in a to filter which point cloud data is rendered (or not)

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.GetAvailablePointCloudRendererFields(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudRendererType)
member.summary: Gets the available fields for the specified renderer type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: Input renderer type
member.remarks:
Each renderer type requires different fields be present on the point cloud layer. If an empty list is returned from GetAvailablePointCloudRendererFields for a given renderer type then it means that that particular renderer type is not supported for the given PointCloudSceneLayer.
If the renderer type is supported then one of the field names returned in the list must be set as the value when defining the new renderer to be used.
Setting an invalid renderer on the layer will disable rendering of the layer until it is removed
member.returns: IReadOnlyList{ }
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.ConstructPolygonSymbol(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMColor,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SimpleStipplePattern)
member.summary: Constructs a polygon symbol of specific color and stipple pattern.
member.param: Outline and stipple color
member.remarks: The polygon symbol outline and stipple color will be the same. The background fill will be white. Note: the stipple pattern is generated with a marker not a fill.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.ConstructPolygonSymbol(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMColor,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SimpleStipplePattern,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMColor)
member.summary: Constructs a polygon symbol of specific color, fill color, and stipple pattern.
member.remarks: The polygon symbol outline and stipple color are specified with "color". The underlying fill color is specified via "fillColor". Fill color can be null to create a hollow background fill. Note: the stipple pattern is generated with a marker not a fill.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.ConstructPolygonSymbol(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMFill,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMStroke,ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMColor,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SimpleStipplePattern)
member.summary: Constructs a polygon symbol with a specific fill, stroke, and stipple pattern.
member.remarks: Specifying a null fill creates a stipple symbol with no background fill. Specifying a null stroke creates a stipple symbol with no outline. The stipple color is specified with "color". Note: the stipple pattern is generated with a marker not a fill.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.ConstructProceduralSymbol(System.String,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMPrimitiveOverride})
member.summary: Create a symbol reference with a procedural symbol layer for a rule package. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Pass in null (default) for the overrides parameter to have default field mappings applied in the renderer
member.param: full path to a rule package
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
{rulePackagePath} not found or is inaccessible
Invalid layer geometry type
Rule package geometry type not compatible with FeatureClass geometry type.
Procedural symbol cannot be applied to rasterized feature layers. Feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group in the Contents pane are rasterized
Call to retrieve rule package attributes failed.
Cannot use rule packages that create leaf shapes with procedural symbols.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.LayerIsCompatibleWithRulePackage(System.String,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer)
member.summary: Checks the compatibility of the rule package geometry with the feature layer shape type for use as a renderer. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Checks:
The rule package is supported (geometry output type must be combined shape)
The output geometry of the features (in the feature layer) is one of "Point | Polygon | Multi-path"
The feature layer is not flattened (i.e. Procedural symbols cannot be applied to feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group. They will be rasterized. Procedural symbols can only be applied to layers in the 3D Layers group
The input geometry type of the rule package matches the geometry type of the layer
member.param: The full path to the rule package
The layer to check the compatibility of the rule package against
member.returns: True if the geometry type of the rule package matches the geometry type of the layer
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
{rulePackagePath} not found or is inaccessible
Cannot use rule packages that create leaf shapes with procedural symbols.
Invalid layer geometry type.
Procedural symbol cannot be applied to rasterized feature layers. Feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group in the Contents pane are rasterized

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ISymbolFactory.ShapeTypeSupportedWithRulePackage(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer)
member.summary: Checks if the underlying shape type of the layer features is supported for use with rule package renderers. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Point, Polygon, and Multipatch shape types are supported.
member.param: The layer to check the shapetype of
member.returns: bool
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

Fill color can be null to create a hollow background fill. To create a stipple fill with no outline, use . Note: the stipple pattern is generated with a marker not a fill.

This method must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run

member.summary: Create a symbol reference with a procedural symbol layer for a rule package. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Pass in null (default) for the overrides parameter to have default field mappings applied in the renderer
member.param: full path to a rule package
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
{rulePackagePath} not found or is inaccessible
Invalid layer geometry type
Rule package geometry type not compatible with FeatureClass geometry type.
Procedural symbol cannot be applied to rasterized feature layers. Feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group in the Contents pane are rasterized
Call to retrieve rule package attributes failed.
Cannot use rule packages that create leaf shapes with procedural symbols.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SymbolFactory.LayerIsCompatibleWithRulePackage(System.String,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FeatureLayer)
member.summary: Checks the compatibility of the rule package geometry with the feature layer shape type for use as a renderer. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
Checks:
The rule package is supported (geometry output type must be combined shape)
The output geometry of the features (in the feature layer) is one of "Point | Polygon | Multi-path"
The feature layer is not flattened (i.e. Procedural symbols cannot be applied to feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group. They will be rasterized. Procedural symbols can only be applied to layers in the 3D Layers group
The input geometry type of the rule package matches the geometry type of the layer
member.param: The full path to the rule package
The layer to check the compatibility of the rule package against
member.returns: True if the geometry type of the rule package matches the geometry type of the layer
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
{rulePackagePath} not found or is inaccessible
Cannot use rule packages that create leaf shapes with procedural symbols.
Invalid layer geometry type.
Procedural symbol cannot be applied to rasterized feature layers. Feature layers that are in the 2D Layers group in the Contents pane are rasterized

member.summary: Checks if the underlying shape type of the layer features is supported for use with rule package renderers. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Point, Polygon, and Multipatch shape types are supported.
member.param: The layer to check the shapetype of
member.returns: bool
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane
member.summary: Derive from TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane to continue to show the TOC of an associated MapView when your (derived) pane is activated. The MapView with the relevant TOC should be set in your Initialize override via the SetMapUri instance method.
member.remarks:
Typically, consumers will derive from instead which provides full impersonation of a MapPane and its associated MapView.
If you do use TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane then your derived class is responsible for handling any enabled state change, visibility change, etc. relevant to the MapView, whose TOC you are showing, being closed

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BooleanToGridLengthConverter
member.summary: Represents a converter that converts Boolean values to GridLength values. A boolean value of True returns a GridLength value of * and a boolean value of False returns a GridLength value of Auto. This can be inverted using Not=False.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BooleanToGridLengthConverter.Not
member.summary: Gets or sets whether True == *, the default, or False == *.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BindableSelectedItemBehavior
member.summary: Binding behavior to work around SelectedItem property of TreeView being readonly Take from Stack Overflow question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1000040/data-binding-to-selecteditem-in-a-wpf-treeview

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.FocusOnFirstItemWhenReceivingKeydoardFocusBehavior
member.summary: Tab navigation helper forcing the keyboard focus to go on the first TreeViewItem each time we navigate to the TreeView (using the tab navigation)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PreventTreeViewItemSelectionOnMouseLeaveBehavior
member.summary: This behavior prevents an incorrect selection of a treeViewItem on mouse leave: if a button within a treeViewItem has been clicked, on mouse leave the focus manager sets back the focus on the treeViewItem which in turn triggers its selection, we want to avoid this.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.AllowBackwardTabNavigationWithinTreeViewBehavior
member.summary: This behavior fixes a known issue of backward navigation not being allowed within a Windows TreeViewItem. The regular behavior when using Shift + Tab within a windows TreeView is to navigate back to the element before the TreeView. To fix this, we test which element is focused to allow the backward navigation within the elements of a TreeViewItem.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Voxel.LockedSectionDefinition
member.summary: Represents the definition of a locked section. Refer to
member.remarks: A locked section is a "dynamic" section that has been locked or "tied" to a specific voxel variable. Once locked, the section position and orientation can no longer be changed and are not updated if the selected voxel variable profile is changed. Locked sections are useful for comparing sections for different variable profiles. Refer to Voxel layer sections

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Voxel.VoxelVariableProfile
member.summary: Represents a variable for a value stored within a voxel cube.
member.remarks: Voxel layers are structured in dimensional regularly gridded cubes or "voxels" which store one or more variables. The variables can store values for either quantitative continuous data or qualitative discrete data. Temperature measurements are represented as continuous data. Other data, such as lithography classes of an underground model, are discrete. Refer to

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.VoxelLayer
member.summary: A voxel layer represents multidimensional spatial and temporal information in a 3D volumetric visualization.
member.remarks:
Use voxel layers to visualize atmospheric or oceanic data, a geological underground model, or space-time cubes.
Voxel layers are sourced from volumetric data stored using NetCDF.
Voxel layers are supported in Local Scenes only. Refer to . Use of Voxel layers requires an Advanced licensing level

member.summary: Gets or creates the CIMMapTableView for a MapMember. If the table pane has been opened for this MapMember, it will initialize the CIMMapTableView with the previous values. If table pane has never been opened, it will initialize the CIMMapTableView with the default table pane values.
member.param: The pane collection.
The mapMember for which the table pane will be opened
member.returns: Return a object, if the MapMember can be opened by the table pane. It returns null if the MapMember can't be opened by the table pane or if the active MapView does not contain the MapMember.
